title: Scope and Purpose
text: These rules govern the procedure in all civil actions and proceedings in the United States district courts, except as stated in Rule 81. They should be construed, administered, and employed by the court and the parties to secure the just, speedy, and inexpensive determination of every action and proceeding.
notes: Fundamental principle guiding all federal civil procedure

title: General Rules of Pleading
text: A pleading that states a claim for relief must contain: (1) a short and plain statement of the grounds for the court's jurisdiction; (2) a short and plain statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief; and (3) a demand for the relief sought.
notes: Notice pleading standard, modified by Twombly and Iqbal plausibility requirements

title: Defenses and Objections: When and How Presented
text: Every defense to a claim for relief in any pleading must be asserted in the responsive pleading if one is required. A party may assert defenses by motion including: lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, lack of personal jurisdiction, improper venue, insufficient process, insufficient service of process, failure to state a claim, and failure to join a party.
notes: Most commonly used for motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim

title: Amended and Supplemental Pleadings
text: A party may amend its pleading once as a matter of course within 21 days after serving it, or if responsive pleading required, 21 days after service of responsive pleading or Rule 12 motion. Otherwise, party may amend only with opposing party's written consent or court's leave, which should be freely given when justice so requires.
notes: Liberal amendment policy encourages resolution on merits

title: Pretrial Conferences; Scheduling; Management
text: The court must issue a scheduling order within 90 days after defendant served or 60 days after defendant appears. The order must limit time to join parties, amend pleadings, complete discovery, and file motions.
notes: Critical for establishing case timeline and deadlines

title: Duty to Disclose; General Provisions Governing Discovery
text: Parties must, without awaiting a discovery request, provide to other parties initial disclosures including: individuals with discoverable information, documents and ESI, computation of damages, and insurance agreements. Discovery scope includes any nonprivileged matter relevant to any party's claim or defense and proportional to the needs of the case.
notes: 2015 amendments emphasize proportionality in discovery

title: Depositions by Oral Examination
text: A party may depose any person by oral questions. Reasonable written notice must be given stating time and place of deposition and deponent's name. Deposition limited to one day of 7 hours unless otherwise ordered or parties stipulate.
notes: Seven-hour limit per deposition day

title: Interrogatories to Parties
text: A party may serve on any other party no more than 25 written interrogatories, including all discrete subparts. Interrogatories must be answered separately and fully in writing under oath within 30 days.
notes: Limited to 25 interrogatories including subparts

title: Producing Documents, ESI, and Tangible Things
text: A party may serve on any other party a request to produce and permit inspection of designated documents, ESI, or tangible things in responding party's possession, custody, or control. Response must be served within 30 days stating objections or that inspection will be permitted.
notes: ESI provisions added to address electronic discovery

title: Requests for Admission
text: A party may serve on any other party a written request to admit, for purposes of the pending action only, the truth of any matters within the scope of Rule 26(b)(1) relating to: facts, application of law to fact, or opinions about either; and the genuineness of any described documents. Matter is admitted unless party serves written answer or objection within 30 days.
notes: Unanswered requests are deemed admitted

title: Failure to Make Disclosures or to Cooperate in Discovery; Sanctions
text: On motion, court may order party to provide discovery and may award reasonable expenses including attorney's fees. If party fails to obey order, court may issue sanctions including: directing facts be taken as established, prohibiting evidence, striking pleadings, staying proceedings, dismissal, default judgment, or contempt.
notes: Escalating sanctions for discovery violations

title: Subpoena
text: Subpoena may command each person to: attend and testify; produce documents, ESI, or tangible things; or permit inspection of premises. Subpoena must issue from court where action is pending and state court's name. Non-party subpoena must be served at least 14 days before compliance required.
notes: Used for discovery from non-parties

title: Summary Judgment
text: Court shall grant summary judgment if movant shows that there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact and movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Party asserting fact is genuinely disputed must support assertion by citing to materials in record or showing that materials cited do not establish absence of genuine dispute.
notes: May be filed any time until 30 days after close of discovery

title: Injunctions and Restraining Orders
text: Court may issue preliminary injunction only on notice to adverse party. Temporary restraining order may be granted without notice only if movant shows immediate and irreparable injury will result, movant's attorney certifies efforts to give notice, and order states why notice should not be required. TRO expires after 14 days unless extended.
notes: Requires showing of likelihood of success and irreparable harm

title: Test for Relevant Evidence
text: Evidence is relevant if: (a) it has any tendency to make a fact more or less probable than it would be without the evidence; and (b) the fact is of consequence in determining the action.
notes: Foundation for all evidence admissibility

title: Excluding Relevant Evidence for Prejudice, Confusion, or Other Reasons
text: The court may exclude relevant evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by danger of: unfair prejudice, confusing the issues, misleading the jury, undue delay, wasting time, or needlessly presenting cumulative evidence.
notes: Balancing test frequently invoked to exclude evidence

title: Character Evidence; Crimes or Other Acts
text: Evidence of a person's character or character trait is not admissible to prove that on a particular occasion the person acted in accordance with the character or trait. Evidence of a crime, wrong, or other act is not admissible to prove a person's character in order to show that on a particular occasion the person acted in accordance with the character. It may be admissible for another purpose, such as proving motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, absence of mistake, or lack of accident.
notes: Propensity evidence generally inadmissible; numerous exceptions

title: Privilege in General
text: The common law — as interpreted by United States courts in the light of reason and experience — governs a claim of privilege unless any of the following provides otherwise: the United States Constitution; a federal statute; or rules prescribed by the Supreme Court. In a civil case, state law governs privilege regarding a claim or defense for which state law supplies the rule of decision.
notes: Incorporates common law privileges including attorney-client and work product

title: Attorney-Client Privilege and Work Product; Limitations on Waiver
text: Disclosure of communication or information covered by attorney-client privilege or work-product protection does not operate as waiver in federal or state proceeding if: disclosure was inadvertent, holder took reasonable steps to prevent disclosure, and holder promptly took reasonable steps to rectify error.
notes: Protects against waiver from inadvertent disclosure in discovery

title: Witness Competency
text: Every person is competent to be a witness unless these rules provide otherwise. In a civil case, state law governs the witness's competency regarding a claim or defense for which state law supplies the rule of decision.
notes: Presumes all witnesses competent to testify

title: Testimony by Expert Witnesses
text: A witness who is qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education may testify in the form of an opinion or otherwise if: (a) expert's scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will help trier of fact; (b) testimony based on sufficient facts or data; (c) testimony is product of reliable principles and methods; and (d) expert reliably applied principles and methods to facts of case.
notes: Daubert standard for expert testimony admissibility

title: Definitions That Apply to This Article; Exclusions from Hearsay
text: Hearsay means a statement that: (1) the declarant does not make while testifying at the current trial or hearing; and (2) a party offers in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted in the statement. The following are not hearsay: prior inconsistent statement, prior consistent statement, statement of identification, and opposing party's statement.
notes: Defines hearsay and non-hearsay statements

title: Exceptions to the Rule Against Hearsay—Regardless of Whether the Declarant Is Available
text: The following are not excluded by rule against hearsay, regardless of declarant availability: present sense impression, excited utterance, then-existing mental/emotional/physical condition, statement for medical diagnosis/treatment, recorded recollection, business records, public records, and numerous other exceptions.
notes: Contains 23 separate hearsay exceptions

title: Summary Judgment and Summary Adjudication
text: A party may move for summary judgment in an action or proceeding if it is contended that the action has no merit or that there is no defense to the action. The motion shall be granted if all the papers submitted show that there is no triable issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.
notes: Motion must be served at least 75 days before hearing

title: Misuses of the Discovery Process
text: Misuses of the discovery process include: (a) persisting in the demand for information that is unreasonable; (b) making an evasive response to discovery; (c) disobeying a court order; (d) making frivolous discovery requests; (e) failing to confer to resolve discovery dispute; (f) failing to respond or submit to authorized discovery method.
notes: Foundation for California discovery sanctions

title: Offer to Compromise
text: Evidence of an offer to compromise a claim is not admissible to prove liability for the claim or its amount.
notes: Encourages settlement negotiations by protecting offers from admission

title: Motion for Summary Judgment
text: Any party may move for summary judgment in any action after issue has been joined. Motion shall be granted if, upon all papers and proof submitted, cause of action or defense shall be established sufficiently to warrant court as matter of law in directing judgment. Motion must be made no later than 120 days after filing of note of issue except with leave of court on good cause shown.
notes: Timing tied to note of issue filing

title: Scope of Disclosure
text: There shall be full disclosure of all matter material and necessary in the prosecution or defense of an action. Information is material and necessary when it bears on the controversy which will help prepare for trial by sharpening issues and reducing delay and prolixity.
notes: More liberal than federal relevance standard

title: Appeal as of Right—When Taken
text: In a civil case, notice of appeal must be filed with district court clerk within 30 days after entry of judgment or order appealed from. When United States or its officer or agency is party, notice of appeal may be filed within 60 days.
notes: Strictly enforced jurisdictional deadline

title: Form of Briefs, Appendices, and Other Papers
text: A brief must: contain a certificate of compliance; be reproduced using proportionally spaced typeface with serifs of at least 14 points; and not exceed type-volume limitation of 13,000 words for principal brief or 6,500 words for reply brief.
notes: Word count limits strictly enforced
